Breaststroke.title: Breaststroke Technique
Breaststroke.content: Breaststroke is a swimming stroke where the swimmer is on their chest and moves their arms in a half-circle motion while kicking with a frog-like kick. It is a slower stroke, making it ideal for distance swimming. Key elements include maintaining proper body position (horizontal and streamlined), breathing at the correct moments, and coordinating the arm and leg movements.
Breaststroke.breathing: In breaststroke, breathe during the arm recovery phase. As your arms sweep back, lift your head slightly out of the water, take a deep breath, and then return your head to the water as your arms move forward.

Freestyle.title: Freestyle Technique
Freestyle.content: Freestyle, also known as front crawl, is the fastest swimming stroke, where the swimmer alternates their arms while flutter kicking. It's a high-speed stroke that requires excellent coordination of breathing, arm movement, and leg kicks. Focus on long, powerful strokes and an efficient flutter kick to maintain speed.
Freestyle.breathing: In freestyle, breathe every two or three strokes. As one arm pulls underwater, turn your head to the side to take a breath. Ensure that your head stays aligned with your body to minimize resistance.

Backstroke.title: Backstroke Technique
Backstroke.content: Backstroke is a stroke where the swimmer lies on their back and alternates arm movements while performing a flutter kick. It is the only stroke swum on the back and requires good balance and core strength to maintain a straight line in the water.
Backstroke.breathing: In backstroke, the swimmer should keep their face above the water at all times, so breathing is natural. Focus on a steady rhythm and avoid holding your breath.

Butterfly.title: Butterfly Stroke Technique
Butterfly.content: The butterfly stroke is a fast, dynamic swimming stroke that involves both arms moving in a circular motion while performing a dolphin kick. This stroke requires high coordination and strength, particularly in the chest and shoulders.
Butterfly.breathing: In butterfly, the swimmer breathes as their arms pull through the water. At the peak of the arm recovery, lift your head out of the water and take a breath. Keep your movements smooth to avoid excessive splashing.

Individual Medley (IM).title: Individual Medley (IM) Technique
Individual Medley (IM).content: The Individual Medley (IM) is a race where the swimmer swims all four strokes in the following order: butterfly, backstroke, breaststroke, and freestyle. Transitioning between each stroke requires precision and strategy.
Individual Medley (IM).breathing: Breathing techniques vary by stroke. Focus on maintaining a steady rhythm during each transition and conserve energy, especially during the butterfly and breaststroke phases.

Medley Relay.title: Medley Relay Technique
Medley Relay.content: The Medley Relay involves four swimmers, each swimming one of the four strokes (butterfly, backstroke, breaststroke, and freestyle) in the IM order. A strong, efficient transition between swimmers is crucial.
Medley Relay.breathing: In the relay, focus on efficient breathing during each stroke while ensuring smooth handoffs with your teammates. Anticipate the start of your leg by breathing rhythmically.

Open Water Swimming.title: Open Water Swimming Technique
Open Water Swimming.content: Open water swimming takes place in natural bodies of water. Techniques include sighting and endurance, with swimmers typically using the freestyle stroke. In open water, swimmers need to deal with waves, currents, and the lack of lane markers.
Open Water Swimming.breathing: Breathing in open water requires extra awareness since the swimmerâ€™s head is often out of sync with their strokes. Sighting (looking ahead) can help with navigation, but always make sure to take deep, controlled breaths to avoid fatigue.

Breathing Drills.title: Breathing Techniques and Drills
Breathing Drills.content: Breathing is essential to all swimming strokes. Mastering breath control and efficiency is key for maintaining endurance and speed. Here are some techniques to improve your breathing:

drills.title: 3-3-3 Breathing Drill
drills.description: Swim freestyle for three strokes, then breathe to your left for three strokes, then breathe to your right for three strokes. Repeat for a set distance to develop bilateral breathing.

drills.title: Exhalation Drill
drills.description: Practice exhaling fully underwater before taking a breath to increase lung capacity and improve efficiency. This drill helps swimmers avoid the tendency to hold their breath.

Kick Drills.title: Kick Drills Technique
Kick Drills.content: Kick drills are essential for improving leg strength and kicking technique for all strokes. These drills focus on developing efficient kicks that help propel the swimmer through the water.

Pull Drills.title: Pull Drills Technique
Pull Drills.content: Pull drills focus on arm movements and technique, helping to build upper body strength and improve stroke efficiency for all strokes. These drills emphasize the pull phase of the stroke.
